awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Explaining Differential Success in Biodiversity Knowledge Commons
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists increasingly rely on community-governed digital portals to store and access open data. While these digital portals have improved access to data and other scientific
products, portals are expensive to implement, challenging to maintain, and often fail to have uptake among key stakeholders. Like those working in other areas of the digital economy, scientists have increasingly adopted platforms to implement and tailor portals to particular communities and needs, a model that lowers infrastructure costs and enables benefits of scale across networked portals. Yet portals built from the same platform nonetheless show a large variation in their outcomes. Participation in any particular portal is often short-lived and the impacts of data portals on the scientific process are challenging to evaluate; portal usage typically fails to map onto traditional measures of research productivity such as publications and citation counts. This project is the first to systematically investigate scientific data portals built from a common platform in order to understand portal communities and outcomes. The research design, which compares biodiversity data portals, will inform studies of other platforms and digital knowledge commons, such as open source software and peer-production communities. Specific findings and recommendations will be shared with biodiversity portal stakeholders regarding the effective design and use of these portals in order to improve uptake and access to these important species data and facilitate science and decision making around environmental change.

This project uses fuzzy set Qualitative Comparative Analysis (fsQCA) to analyze open data portals as a kind of knowledge commons that impose minimal restrictions on access or reuse. The study sample comprises the 37 active and 4 inactive biodiversity data portals built from the Symbiota platform, one of the largest and earliest scientific data platforms still under continual development, with hundreds of participating biodiversity collections and several dozen individually managed portals. In 2020, Symbiota portals collectively provided
access to over 60 million biodiversity data records and accounted for 90% of Web traffic accessing specimens digitized through the NSF’s Advanced Digitization of Biodiversity Collections (ADBC) program, which has invested over $50 million in this area to date. The project synthesizes across multiple types and sources of quantitative and qualitative data to identify why some of these portals achieve sustained growth and others do not. To do so, the project collects and analyzes up to ten years of analytics and other information from the portals, including tracked usage data, community building activities, features of portal governance, and resource inputs, as well as observation data collected during portal site visits and interviews with a stratified sample of portal managers. The fsQCA approach enables comparative inferences about those portal features most likely to foster productive and sustained outcomes, including collective benefit and building inclusive scientific communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Harnessing the value of big data for science relies on aggregating many data records into a pooled resource available for computational analysis. Encouraged by funders, industry, and other researchers, scientists are increasingly making their data available in the public domain through submitting it to digital repositories or “portals” that impose minimal restrictions on access or reuse. While the current ecosystem of scientific data portals provides immense societal and commercial value, even the largest and best-funded repositories have struggled to achieve long-term sustainability in the face of uncertain funding, personnel resources, and rapid innovation. Mirroring trends in the economy at large, scientists are increasingly adopting platforms as an attractive model for lowering infrastructure costs while generating network benefits. However, until now, no study of scientific data commons has yet investigated how these platforms operate or leveraged them to conduct a systematic analysis of why portals using the same platform still typically show a large variation in outcomes.

This project was the first to identify key determinants of outcomes for 40+ biodiversity data portals using the Symbiota content management platform by integrating the rich tracking data it provides with insights from qualitative interviews and software/user guides. The Symbiota platform itself is one of the largest and earliest scientific data platforms still under development, with hundreds of participating institutions and thousands of data managers. Symbiota has become the standard for National Science Foundation (NSF) projects funding the digitization and curation of specimen records from natural history collections and the NSF’s National Ecological Observatory Network in the U.S. The project team conducted, transcribed, and analyzed 91 interviews with portal leaders and contributors drawn from across the population of Symbiota portal communities. We also coded over fifty portal documents outlining data contributions and curation contexts in Symbiota and across three other biodiversity portals. 

Key findings of the project include insights on social and technical dimensions of portal communities, operations, and governance. Member perceptions and practices of data portal communities vary widely; portal communities are not monolithic, nor can communities be entirely explained by external factors such as funding or community attributes such as membership size. Data portals are perceived by the science, collections, and natural resource communities as valuable assets for a variety of purposes in addition to their function as digital data repositories. This has implications for the governance of portals (both self-governance and externally managed) because it suggests that “one size fits all” approaches to data communities are prone to organizational failure. From a knowledge commons perspective, data are not the only element perceived to be held “in common” by these communities; members point to a range of tangible and intangible community elements as important to their success. Additionally, it is possible to systematically analyze non-traditional documents such as software rules and user guidelines using the Institutional Grammar (IG) to uncover rule structures governing data sharing and use. Emerging data governance principles, such as the FAIR Data Principles, influence participation in biodiversity science by changing how the fitness-for-use of datasets are evaluated based on the interests and needs of different social groups. 

For broader education impacts, the project supported the creation of new training modules and workshops on institutional analysis and policy studies. These efforts have benefited a total of 29 graduate students who participated in annual IG training workshops beginning in 2022. Additionally, online IG training has provided approximately 100 to 150 students, faculty, and practitioners interested in learning the IG with asynchronous IG training materials. These were supplemented by a series of live, interactive training sessions with the IG instructors, in which approximately 10-25 students participated annually since 2022.  The project also trained two graduate student research assistants; one in biodiversity informatics at ASU (analytics and quantitative analysis of portal activities) and one in anthropology at Purdue (qualitative data analysis and systematic literature review).


Last Modified: 04/24/2025
Modified by: Beckett Sterner
